items.title: The Lumon Terminal Pro computer pops up on Apple’s website
19 founders and VCs working with Elon Musk’s DOGE
OpenAI adopts rival Anthropic’s standard for connecting AI models to data
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- OpenAI is adopting Anthropic’s Model Context Protocol (MCP) for its products, enhancing AI assistants' data connectivity.
- CEO Sam Altman announced support for MCP via a post on X, emphasizing its role in improving response relevance.
- MCP allows AI models to interact with various data sources and creates two-way connections, benefiting developers and applications.
- Companies like Block and Replit have already integrated MCP, and OpenAI plans to reveal more about its MCP strategy soon.

items.title: SpaceX reportedly has a secret backdoor for Chinese investment
items.author: Rebecca Bellan
items.summary:
- SpaceX allegedly enables Chinese investors to acquire stakes through offshore routes like the Cayman Islands.
- This practice raises national security concerns, particularly since SpaceX is a defense contractor for the Pentagon.
- CFO Bret Johnsen revealed these details during a corporate dispute regarding a failed $50 million deal with a Chinese firm in 2021.
- Experts express concern that this strategy indicates efforts to obscure foreign investment interests in the company.
- Previous investigations suggest that Chinese investors use special-purpose vehicles to invest in Musk-controlled companies discreetly.

items.title: Leaked data exposes a Chinese AI censorship machine
items.summary:
- A leaked database reveals China’s development of an AI system designed to flag sensitive content, with 133,000 examples provided for training.
- The censorship system targets not just traditional taboos but also current socio-political issues in China, such as corruption and public dissent.
- Researchers express concern that AI technology is being adapted by authoritarian regimes to enhance information control and repression.

items.title: Bradley Tusk says he makes more money with ‘equity-for-services’ than he did as a traditional VC
items.author: Rebecca Bellan
items.summary:
- Bradley Tusk, managing partner at Tusk Venture Partners, claims traditional VC is dead.
- Tusk shifts to an ‘equity-for-services’ model, offering expertise in regulatory navigation in return for equity.
- He highlights the challenges faced by VCs, such as high interest rates and stymied IPOs, and the disillusionment with the traditional VC model.
- Tusk emphasizes making more money through equity-for-services, retaining 100% of the proceeds instead of sharing with investors.
- His firm, Tusk Venture Partners, will continue to support existing portfolio companies until 2031.

items.title: Fintech Mercury lands $300M in Sequoia-led Series C, doubles valuation to $3.5B
items.author: Mary Ann Azevedo
items.summary:
- Mercury has raised $300 million in a Series C funding round, doubling its valuation to $3.5 billion.
- The previous Series B funding round in 2021 valued the company at $1.62 billion.
- Sequoia led the Series C round, with participation from other investors like Coatue and Andreessen Horowitz.
- Mercury reported $500 million in revenue in 2024, with 10 consecutive quarters of profitability.
- The company serves over 200,000 customers and achieved a 40% year-over-year customer growth.
- Mercury plans to launch a consumer banking product later in 2024 and is looking to expand through acquisitions.

items.title: Nuclear startup Terrestrial Energy goes public via SPAC, netting $280 million in merger
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- Terrestrial Energy merges with an acquisition company, netting $280 million.
- The Canadian company focuses on small modular reactors, planning to list on Nasdaq under the symbol ISMR.
- Designed to address past molten salt reactor issues, their reactor core will be replaced every seven years, incorporating advanced safety and cooling systems.
- Target markets include electric power, data centers, and industrial applications.
- Renewed interest in nuclear power linked to increasing electricity demand from electrification and data centers.
- Other tech companies, including Google and Amazon, are also exploring advanced nuclear solutions.

items.title: Has GetReal cracked the code on AI deepfakes? $18M and an impressive client list says yes
items.summary:
- GetReal raises $17.5 million in Series A funding for AI deepfake detection tools aimed at governments and enterprises.
- The company offers a forensics platform with features like a threat exposure dashboard and tools for safeguarding high-profile individuals.
- Key investors include Forgepoint Capital, Cisco Investments, and Capital One Ventures, with notable customers like John Deere and Visa.

items.title: A new social app is fighting rage-bait
items.author: Joe Trippi
items.summary:
- Sez Us, a social app founded by Joe Trippi, aims to eliminate rage-bait from online discourse.
- Rage-bait posts are designed to create controversy and drive engagement, influencing platforms like Instagram, TikTok, and YouTube.
- Users on Sez Us can rate posts based on approval, insightfulness, relevance, and politeness, promoting more constructive conversations.

items.title: YouTube is changing how YouTube Shorts views are counted
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- YouTube is altering its view-counting method for Shorts to improve creator insights.
- New views will count each time a Short starts or replays, increasing total view counts.
- The change aligns YouTube's metrics with [TikTok](https://ads.tiktok.com/help/article/video-play?lang=en) and [Instagram Reels](https://help.instagram.com/202865988324236).
- Creators can view an older metric called “engaged views” in YouTube Analytics.
- This update does not affect how creators earn money or qualify for the YouTube Partner Program.
- The new counting method goes into effect on March 31, 2025.

items.title: Waze removes Google Assistant from iOS due to ongoing issues
items.author: Lauren Forristal
items.summary:
- Waze has officially discontinued the integration of Google Assistant for iOS due to unresolved issues since 2020.
- Ongoing problems reported by users included the microphone not responding in the app.
- Waze plans to introduce an enhanced voice interaction solution and has been testing an AI-powered 'Conversational Reporting' feature since October 2024.
- Android users can still access Google Assistant for Waze, while a transition to Gemini is underway for other platforms by Google.

items.title: Amazon’s Alexa Fund is now backing AI startups
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Amazon’s Alexa Fund, established in 2015, is expanding its focus from early-stage voice startups to AI solutions.
- The fund aims to invest in AI-enabled hardware, smart agents, and generative media following the rise of large language models and Amazon's Gen AI-powered Alexa+.
- Four new startups have received investment: NinjaTech AI, Hedra, Ario, and HeyBoss, each operating in various AI and tech domains.

items.title: What’s next for ATProto, the protocol powering Bluesky and other apps
Krisp is using AI to help Indians sound like Americans on calls
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Krisp launches a feature to change accents during calls, starting with Indian English to U.S. English.
- The technology preserves the speaker's voice while altering phonemes for better understanding.
- The idea emerged from co-founder Arto Minasyan's personal experiences with accent comprehension.
- Initial beta testing showed a 26.1% increase in sales conversion and a 14.8% rise in revenue.
- Future plans include adding more accents and expanding to iOS and Android apps.

items.title: The TikTok ban is losing support among Americans, study says
items.author: Amanda Silberling
items.summary:
- A new study by the [Pew Research Center](https://www.pewresearch.org/short-reads/2025/03/25/fewer-americans-now-support-tiktok-ban-see-the-platform-as-a-national-security-threat-than-in-spring-2023/?utm_source=AdaptiveMailer&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=25-03-25%20TikTok%20ban%20short%20read&org=982&lvl=100&ite=15726&lea=4249848&ctr=0&par=1&trk=a0DQm0000053vznMAA) shows support for a TikTok ban among Americans has decreased from 50% in 2023 to 34% in 2025.
- Opposition to the ban has risen, from 22% in 2023 to 32% in the latest survey.
- Support for the ban has dropped significantly among all political affiliations, notably among Republicans from 60% to 30% and Democrats from 43% to 30%.
- TikTok users are less likely to support the ban (12%) compared to non-users (45%).
- Bipartisan support for banning TikTok still exists, with legislation signed into law by former President Biden last year due to national security concerns regarding Chinese ownership by ByteDance.

items.title: Amazon launches personalized shopping prompts as part of its generative AI push
items.author: Lauren Forristal
items.summary:
- Amazon introduced a new feature called "Interests" to enhance personalized shopping through AI.
- Customers can now use tailored prompts in the search bar based on their interests and budget.
- The tool utilizes large language models to convert simple language into search queries for more relevant product suggestions.
- Interests will notify users of new items, restocks, and deals related to their interests.
- Currently available to a select group of users in the U.S. via the Amazon Shopping app and mobile website.
- Amazon plans to extend access to more customers in the coming months.

items.title: Countdown: 5 days left to save up to $320 on TechCrunch All Stage passes
Google fixes Chrome zero-day security flaw used in hacking campaign targeting journalists
items.author: Zack Whittaker
items.summary:
- Google fixed a zero-day vulnerability in Chrome tracked as CVE-2025-2783, exploited in a hacking campaign.
- The bug allowed hackers to bypass Chrome's sandbox protections, affecting all browsers based on Chromium.
- Kaspersky linked the exploit to a phishing campaign named ‘Operation ForumTroll’, targeting Russian media and educational institutions.
- Chrome updates with the fix will roll out in the coming days and weeks.

items.title: Rivian spins out a new micromobility startup called Also with $105M from Eclipse
items.summary:
- Rivian has spun out a micromobility startup named Also, which has received $105 million from Eclipse Ventures.
- Also's team consists of around 70 members from companies like Apple, Google, and Tesla.
- The startup will focus on affordable micromobility solutions and plans to launch its first product, which will have a bike-like form factor, next year in the US and Europe.
- Chris Yu, Rivian’s VP of future programs, will serve as the president of Also.
- Rivian holds a minority stake in the new company and plans to leverage its technology and retail presence.

items.title: Cloud veterans launch ConfigHub to fix ‘configuration hell’
items.author: Alexis Richardson, Brian Grant, Jesper Joergensen
items.summary:
- A trio of cloud industry leaders launched ConfigHub with a mission to modernize software configuration data management.  
- The company has emerged from stealth with $4 million in funding and aims to help users escape 'configuration hell'.  
- Key executives include CEO Alexis Richardson (Weaveworks founder), CTO Brian Grant (original lead architect of Kubernetes), and CPO Jesper Joergensen (formerly of Salesforce).  
- ConfigHub will offer a unified database for configuration management, simplifying error tracking and resolution.  
- The company plans to target Kubernetes DevOps tooling and has partnered with medium to large enterprises for product development.  
- ConfigHub’s product is still in development, with a SaaS model on the horizon.  
- Previous configuration incidents highlight the need for better management solutions, especially as AI becomes more prevalent in software operations.

items.title: AI’s coming to the classroom: Brisk raises $15M after a quick start in school
items.summary:
- AI edtech startup Brisk raised $15 million to enhance its platform for teachers and students.
- It provides around 40 tools via a Chrome extension, leveraging generative AI and computer vision to improve educational workflows.
- Brisk plans to integrate with Microsoft by autumn 2025, aiming to expand its user base further.
- The company's user base has grown fivefold since its $5 million seed funding in September 2024, with products used in over 2,000 schools across 100 countries.
- More than 90% of Brisk's business is driven by inbound interest, with one in five K-12 teachers in the U.S. using the extension as of February 2025.
- Future developments include creating a new web platform and multimodal integrations for various types of student work.

items.title: A comprehensive list of 2025 tech layoffs
Microsoft adds AI-powered deep research tools to Copilot
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Microsoft introduces a new AI-powered tool called Researcher within Microsoft 365 Copilot, aimed at enhancing deep research capabilities.
- Researcher is powered by OpenAI's deep research model and includes advanced orchestration and deep search functionalities, enabling analyses such as go-to-market strategies and quarterly reports.
- Analyst, the second tool, uses OpenAI’s o3-mini reasoning model and is optimized for advanced data analysis, capable of running Python for complex queries.
- Unique features include accessing work data and third-party data connectors, integrating with tools like Confluence and Salesforce.
- Microsoft launches a Frontier program for exclusive access to these tools, available starting in April for members.
- The challenges of AI reasoning include potential inaccuracies and mis-citations from less reliable sources.

items.title: Read the email Jack Dorsey sent when he cut 931 of Block’s staff
items.author: Charles Rollet, Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- Block laid off 931 employees, about 8% of its staff, as announced in an email by CEO Jack Dorsey.
- The layoffs include 391 for strategy reasons, 460 for performance issues, and 80 managers to flatten the hierarchy.
- Dorsey stated that the cuts are due to strategic needs, not financial ones or AI replacements, and that 748 open roles will also be closed.

items.title: We read the email Jack Dorsey sent when he cut 931 of Block’s staff
items.author: Charles Rollet, Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- Block laid off 931 employees, as revealed in an email from CEO Jack Dorsey.
- Dorsey stated layoffs were due to strategic changes, not financial issues or AI replacements.
- Layoffs categorized into three reasons: 391 for strategy, 460 for performance, and 80 management reductions.
- All 748 open roles at Block were closed except for critical positions.
- Previous major layoffs occurred in January 2024, with a total of 12,000 staff prior to the recent cuts.

items.title: How to tell if your online accounts have been hacked
items.summary:
- Hackers increasingly target individuals to access bank accounts, crypto, or for stalking.
- Most major service providers offer tools for account security and recovery.
- Users should enable multi-factor authentication (MFA) to enhance account security.
- It’s crucial to act promptly if signs of hacking are suspected; professionals can assist those at greater risk.
- Specific steps for Gmail, Microsoft Outlook, LinkedIn, and Yahoo are provided to check account security and recent logins.
- Regular updates will be made to keep instructions current for various online services.

items.title: Emergence Capital closes on $1B fund to back B2B companies
items.author: Mary Ann Azevedo
items.summary:
- Emergence Capital has closed its $1 billion seventh fund, reported on Tuesday.
- This is the firm’s first raise in nearly four years; previous fundraise was in May 2021.
- Emergence is focusing heavily on artificial intelligence investment, describing it as a generational opportunity.

items.title: Earth AI’s algorithms found critical minerals in places everyone else ignored
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- Earth AI discovered critical mineral deposits in Australia that were previously overlooked by other mining companies.
- The startup identified deposits of copper, cobalt, gold, silver, molybdenum, and tin in specific regions of the Northern Territory and New South Wales.
- Founded by Roman Teslyuk, Earth AI uses advanced algorithms to analyze historical geological data to make predictions about mineral locations.
- The company aims to revolutionize the slow traditional exploration methods used in the mining industry.
- Earth AI raised $20 million in January 2025, demonstrating growing investor interest in AI-driven mineral exploration.

items.title: Instagram partners with schools to prioritize reports of online bullying and student safety
items.author: Lauren Forristal
items.summary:
- Instagram announced a new school partnership program to expedite handling of moderation reports from verified school accounts.
- The program is available to all middle and high schools in the U.S., allowing them to report posts or accounts that may violate guidelines.
- Participating schools will have a “school partner” banner on their profiles, and Instagram will provide educational resources on safe app usage.
- The initiative follows a year of testing with 60 schools and collaboration with ISTE and ASCD.
- The program comes amid legislative efforts to regulate social media for children, including the Kids Off Social Media Act (KOSMA).

items.title: ChatGPT’s image-generation feature gets an upgrade
items.author: Kyle Wiggers, Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- OpenAI CEO Sam Altman announced a major upgrade to ChatGPT’s image-generation capabilities using the GPT-4o model.
- GPT-4o can now natively create and modify images, a feature previously limited to text generation.
- The upgrade is available for subscribers on the $200/month Pro plan and will roll out soon for Plus and free users as well as developers.
- GPT-4o is designed to create more accurate and detailed images than its predecessor, DALL-E 3.
- OpenAI trained GPT-4o on publicly available data and proprietary data from partnerships, with a commitment to respecting artists' rights.
- The upgrade comes after Google's Gemini 2.0 Flash, which experienced issues with image generation and copyright concerns.

items.title: Apple announces WWDC 2025 takes place June 9-13
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Apple announced that the Worldwide Developers Conference (WWDC) will be held from June 9 to June 13, 2025.
- The event will be online and accessible to all Apple developers, with an in-person keynote at Apple Park on June 9.
- WWDC 2025 will showcase new versions of iOS, iPadOS, macOS, watchOS, and tvOS, as well as new tools for developers.
- Reports suggest significant software updates for the iPhone, iPad, and Mac, with iOS 19 being the most dramatic revamp since iOS 7.
- The event may also introduce new hardware products and enhancements to Siri.

items.title: Apple announces WWDC 2025 returns June 9-13
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
* Apple will host its WWDC 2025 from June 9 to June 13.
* The event will be online and accessible to all Apple developers, with an in-person keynote at Apple Park on June 9.
* Major software updates for iOS, iPadOS, and macOS are expected, with iOS 19 touted as the biggest revamp since iOS 7.
* There may be new hardware products and a smarter Siri announced during the conference.
* The conference focuses on advancements in Apple software and provides developers with access to Apple experts and new tools.

items.title: 23andMe files for bankruptcy: How to delete your data
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- 23andMe filed for bankruptcy protection on March 16, 2025, affecting 15 million customers.
- Concerns raised about the future of customer genetic data and its management under new ownership.
- Users can delete their data through their account settings but some information may still be retained as per the privacy policy.
- Instructions provided on how to revoke consent for research use of genetic data and destroy DNA samples.
- Customers encouraged to motivate family and friends to take protective measures for their data as well.

items.title: Google unveils a next-gen AI reasoning model
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- Google launched **Gemini 2.5 Pro Experimental**, a multimodal AI reasoning model that can pause to think before answering.
- The model is available on **Google AI Studio** and as part of the **Gemini Advanced** subscription plan.
- Gemini 2.5 aims to outshine previous frontier models, claiming better performance in creating web apps and coding applications.
- Gemini 2.5 Pro reportedly achieved a score of **68.6%** in code editing evaluations, surpassing competitors like OpenAI and Anthropic.
- The model will ship with a **1 million token context window**, expandable to **2 million tokens** soon, allowing it to process vast text inputs.

items.title: Quora’s Poe launches its most affordable subscription plan for $5/month
items.author: Lauren Forristal
items.summary:
- Poe, Quora’s chatbot app, launched a $5/month subscription plan on March 25, 2025.
- The new plan allows users to spend up to 10,000 points per day.
- A more expensive plan at $250/month offers 12.5 million points, catering to heavy users.
- Poe allows access to multiple AI bots like DeepSeek-R1, GPT-4o, and Claude 3.7 Sonnet.
- The previous lowest tier was $20/month for 1 million points, and a free plan is also available with limitations.

items.title: Cerebras Systems’ IPO is further delayed
items.summary:
- Cerebras Systems’ IPO is delayed again due to a prolonged national security review.
- Originally filed for IPO in September 2024, expecting easier review with the new Trump administration.
- National security concerns arose from a $335 million investment from Abu Dhabi-based G42, linked to Huawei.
- White House vacancies affect oversight of the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States, causing delays.

items.title: A world without Caesars: How the ATProto community is rebuilding the web to return power to the people
items.summary:
- The first in-person gathering for the AT Protocol community took place in Seattle, focusing on decentralization rather than Bluesky, the largest app built on its framework.
- Over 150 attendees discussed ways to rebuild the web, regain control over data, and lessen reliance on tech oligarchs.
- Speakers included notable figures like Blaine Cook and Jay Graber, who highlighted the challenges and hopes for a decentralized social web.

items.title: Discord made its streaming overlay a lot more user-friendly
items.author: Amanda Silberling
items.summary:
- Discord rebuilt its Overlay feature for streaming games, enhancing user-friendliness for streamers.
- The new Overlay allows customization of specific Discord widgets for quick access while gaming, avoiding the need to open the entire Discord client.
- Features include a picture-in-picture option for viewing friends' streams and compatibility with more games, aiming for smoother performance.
- Additional updates to the Desktop app include new dark themes and UI density options for customization.

items.title: Once a target of Musk’s ire, Gen Z creator Kat Abughazaleh is running for Congress
items.summary:
- Kat Abughazaleh is running for Congress in Illinois’ Ninth District after losing her job at Media Matters.
- She gained attention when Elon Musk celebrated her layoff on social media.
- At 26, Abughazaleh aims to bring progressive ideas and engage Gen Z voters.
- She built a following for her political content, particularly on TikTok and Bluesky.
- In her campaign announcement, she emphasized basic rights for families and affordable living.
- Abughazaleh raised $100,000 in the first seven hours of her campaign, with significant contributions from Bluesky.

items.title: Outreach founder Manny Medina has a new startup that helps AI agents get paid
items.summary:
- Manny Medina, founder of Outreach, has launched a new startup called Paid, aimed at ensuring AI agents get compensated profitably.
- Paid raised €10 million (about $11 million) in a pre-seed investment from EQT Ventures, Sequoia, and GTMFund.
- The platform helps agentic startups establish pricing models based on results rather than traditional per-user or usage charges, addressing the unique billing challenges of AI agents.
- Paid is aimed at startups rather than larger enterprises and has three beta customers: Logic.app, 11x, and Vidlab7.
- Medina emphasizes the need for startups to measure margins and validate ROI in the emerging sector of AI agents.

items.title: Less than a week to save $300+ on TechCrunch All Stage passes
items.summary:
- TechCrunch's All Stage conference is set for July 15 in Boston.
- Early registration before March 31 saves attendees over $300 on passes.
- The conference features sessions, networking opportunities, and breakout stages for early-stage founders.

items.title: Plural’s platform allows enterprises to manage their Kubernetes clusters in one place
items.author: Becca Szkutak
items.summary:
- Sam Weaver, previously at Unqork, identified issues in managing Kubernetes clusters and assembled a team to build a management product, which took two years.
- Michael Guarino, an engineer, created a more efficient system for Plural within weeks, leading to the development of a centralized Kubernetes management platform.
- Plural's AI enhances cluster management by offering optimization suggestions and diagnosing scaling issues, reducing operational overhead by about 90%.
- The company raised $6 million in seed funding, aiming to enhance product capabilities and expand beyond Kubernetes.
- Plural operates on a GitOps model, allowing enterprises complete control without data being sent to a central server.

items.title: Apple Music is integrating with music tools to allow DJs to create mixes using its catalog
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Apple Music is integrating with tools for DJs, allowing them to build mixes using its catalog of over 100 million songs.
- Integrated tools include Algoriddim’s djay Pro, AlphaTheta, Serato, Engine DJ, Denon DJ, Numark, and RANE DJ.
- A new DJ category page will feature DJ-friendly playlists and mixes for inspiration.
- Since launching streaming for DJ Mix sets in 2021, Apple has added thousands of sets to the platform.
- Competitors like SoundCloud and Spotify are also exploring tools for song creation and remixing.

items.title: Tesla Superchargers: GM, Ford, Rivian, and other EV brands with access
items.summary:
- In May 2023, Ford secured a deal granting EV owners access to Tesla's Supercharger network.
- By late 2023, multiple automakers including GM, Hyundai, and Rivian had adopted Tesla’s North American Charging Standard (NACS).
- Tesla has shared its charging connector design to promote widespread adoption.
- As of February 2024, Ford customers were gaining Supercharger access, although adapter supply delays were noted.
- GM started offering Chevy, Cadillac, and GMC EVs access as of September 2024.
- Honda announced its EVs would gain NACS access in June 2025.
- Hyundai plans to provide NACS access by January 15, 2025, and will manufacture some new models with NACS ports.
- Rivian gained access to Superchargers as of March 2024, promising adapters to customers.
- Mercedes-Benz will begin offering access starting February 2025, with an adapter option for existing EVs.
- Nissan's Ariya drivers can access Tesla's network with a NACS adapter starting late 2024.
- Volvo and Polestar began offering access at the end of October 2024, with adapters available for purchase.

items.title: Character AI is adding parental supervision tools to improve teen safety
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Character AI introduces new parental insights features to enhance teen safety.
- The features provide parents with a weekly summary of their teens' activity on the app, including average time spent and top characters interacted with.
- These updates come in response to lawsuits and criticism regarding the platform's safety for children.
- Previous safety measures included a specific model for teens and blocking sensitive content.
- Character AI argues it implemented these features quicker than competitors.

items.title: Bill Gates-backed Commonwealth Fusion Systems hits key reactor construction milestone
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- Commonwealth Fusion Systems (CFS) installed a crucial component for its Sparc demonstration reactor, a 24-foot wide, 75-ton stainless steel cryostat base.
- This component, shipped from Italy to Devens, Massachusetts, is essential for the tokamak, aiming to be the first fusion reactor to generate more power than it consumes.
- CFS has been working on the reactor for over three years and expects Sparc to come online in 2027, hoping it will produce more power than it uses through advanced magnetic confinement techniques.

items.title: Waymo to launch robotaxi service in Washington D.C. in 2026
items.author: Rebecca Bellan
items.summary:
- Waymo plans to offer robotaxi rides in Washington D.C. via the Waymo One app starting in 2026.
- The company must lobby to change existing permits that currently require a human driver.
- Waymo is expanding its robotaxi services, already operating in Phoenix, Los Angeles, the Bay Area, and Austin, with Atlanta and Miami slated for launches in 2026.
- The announcement follows a test fleet launch of Jaguar I-Pace robotaxis in D.C. and plans for mapping in 10 cities this year.

items.title: Daphni secures $215M for its third fund
items.author: Romain Dillet
items.summary:
- French VC firm [Daphni](https://www.daphni.com/) announces the closing of its new fund, Daphni Blue, having raised €200 million (around $215 million).
- The firm expects to reach €250 million ($270 million) in total by the end of the year.
- Daphni plans to invest in another 40 startups, continuing its investment history with 70 European startups since 2015.
- Major limited partners include Crédit Mutuel Arkéa, Bpifrance, and the European Investment Fund.
- Daphni emphasizes investment in fundamental science which includes life sciences, physics, chemistry, and mathematics, as opposed to just artificial intelligence.

items.title: OpenAI says its AI voice assistant is now better to chat with
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- OpenAI updated its Advanced Voice Mode to improve real-time conversations in ChatGPT.
- The update aims to make the AI more personable and reduce interruptions when users pause to think.
- Free users of ChatGPT gain access to the updated voice mode, while paying users experience fewer interruptions and a more engaging personality in responses.
- The improvements come as competitors accelerate their efforts in the AI voice assistant market, including startups like Sesame and larger companies like Amazon preparing their own voice assistants.
